comments.commentBody: It's funny you should mention that. I volunteered with Romani asylum-seekers in London for a year, before the EU expansion. I didn't meet a single adult who wasn't working or looking for work. Sure, there are welfare leeches among Roma (often because they're conditioned to believe no one will employ them, but also because of the way systems are set up). And I have lived among Roma, because I am Romani. You would do well to consider the constant barrage of hate we experience, regardless of our employment status -- including threatening words and physical contact my own children have received from "respectable" adults while as young as two years old. I have plenty of criticism for certain aspects of many Romani cultures, to be sure. One-sided statements such as yours, however, are hardly productive.

I can't find the naked models! I've been on Healthcare.gov for hours, and have signed up for insurance in three states and Medicaid in another four, but still can't find the naked models. What a lousy site.
An overload of users should not crash a website. It should just make things very very slow.  Websites crash because there are software bugs or hardware failures.

Maybe it's a vast right wing conspiracy involving Anonymous and sundry other  hacksters to launch the mother of all denial of service attacks? Obviously we need another alphabet agency to counter this nefarious threat to national security.

Every year, in their rush to see nearly naked models, the overload of millions of viewers crashes the Victoria's Secret fashion show website. I imagine a few million people tried to use the ACA website on the first day it rolled out. If even a company that has had web experience for 20 years crashes with overuse, it hard to imagine that something huge like signing up for ACA insurance would go over without a problem. It will be fixed.

For a while I subscribed to Adoptive Families magazine. My sister flipped through it one day and said, "Don't read this; its real name should be Dysfunctional Adoptive Families."  That was an eye opener.

Wellstone's revenge: How Minnesota Democrats took their state back

http://mojo.ly/HgUhkG

It's going to take a big commitment on the part of many to reverse the inequality.

Now I am 58. I see a pain specialist for other things. I got my third steroid shot yesterday. I have never abused my drug allocation when prescribed. I have a problem with these G-men and there puritanical standards invading my relationship between me and my doctor. What I don't understand is Obama's solution here is the same as wall street. If the financial institutions caused the problems, bail them out and let them have their raises. If doctors are proscribing too many meds, let's reward them by giving them more appointments at the cost of patients. Let's increase those insurance rates. If the doctors are not recognizing addiction or pills being over proscribed what really here is going to changed the behavior. The only thing this is really going to accomplish is increasing the cost to the patient and creating more knee jerk reactions where doctors under proscribe pain medication.

If you need to do something, tax it. Place an excise tax on it and have the money go to an education an enforcement fund. Not only train doctors, but train patients too. The blurbs that come out with the proscriptions are in microprint and written for lawyers. People should know how they work and how they slow their digestive processes so constipation is a normal occurrence. But I guess this is too complex for G-men and the FDA to understand and they rather penalize people.

There are 7 billion people in the world. I tried looking up your figures but got nowhere. Perhaps you could help. Here's what I found:

Mapping the Use of Opiates Across the World
http://www.geocurrents.info/geonotes/mapping-the-use-of-opiates-across-t...

List of countries by prevalence of opiates use - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_prevalence_of_opiates_use

It doesn't look too bad considering the number of foreign wars the U.S. engages in and the number of soldiers coming home facing a lifetime of chronic pain from IEDs. We also live longer than many third world countries and with that comes the pain of old age. So what is your solution to chronic pain? Not deal with it? Slam your door? This is why doctors should never have been granted prescription authority, a power stripped from the public which is now being used as an economic leverage driving Medicare into bankruptcy as the boomer generation ages. Our Founding Fathers had the right to self-medicate. Give the public back its right to medicines without government intervention. This is supposed to be the land of the "free". Is it too much to ask that we be given the right to die in dignity with our Maker, without pain and without the oversight, regulation and intrusions of privacy that now exist?

I suffer from migraines, migraines meds do not work. My doctor has given me only 30 day scripts at a time of Vicodin for my pain. This keeps me out of the ER where I was having to go to get shots to function. I do have to return to him for a follow up visit before he will refill them. 30 day supply usually last me 90 days. As for me I know this cannot be a way of my life for me forever so hopefully once menopause is over this will stop. These meds can be used properly. Docs know who will take them properly and who will not. As far as the dentist goes not giving the meds for teeth, that's just awful!! And the cancer patient too! Pharmacy are good to catch people using double scripts and multiple locations, I have the police called. I teach elementary school and I am always on the lookout for odd things that don't add up with our kids. Our world is a sad place!!

They did the amnesty in 1986 and legalized 3 million who in turn sponsored probably 6-10 million of their near and dear ones. They promised that everything will be alright. Obviously the rules were unenforced.
Now they are ready for the second round and the numbers are 11-15 million who in turn would sponsor another 30-50 million of their close families upon legalization. Can US imagine the social and economic upheaval this would bring about?

This type of movement only helps one ethnic mix (i.e. Latinos) the most and the African Americans will be the big losers the Democrats assiduously court and now they are on the backburner.

I guess anything goes to be in power, it is all about votes and nothing else.

It's too bad our politicians aren't as concerned about creating American jobs as they are about "fairness" for illegal aliens and other foreign nationals. With the economy as it is, the last problem our politicians should be concerned about is the welfare of foreign nationals. They should enforce the immigration laws now on the books instead.  The U.S. already has more Legal immigrants than any other nation. Our immigration rates match those of the 20s and 30s. Enough already.

The priorities here probably are good ones: with money, you can effect SOME justice for those who suffered as the result of wrongdoing; so focus on that first.

We should have more indictments, as well, but that's a lot tougher -- we've been told that behavior may have been unethical, but for a long time (and still) our laws might not have made that behavior illegal. We can fix that with new laws, but we can't try past behavior by new laws: that's a constitutional no-no.

So, I expect to see the money first, then some but not a lot indictments. But I also expect to see new laws that make a lot of what we might think of as fraud but technically wasn't, ACTUAL fraud in future.

Took a while to get this far; but it's good that it's finally happening.

If you buy a house and then the furnace breaks you are the one who has to pay to fix it  not the former owner. It is up to the buyer to check things out. Buying assets involves risk and current shareholders of these banks had to be aware of the dicey actions of these banks. They have decided to buy or hold on to their stock even though it has been clear for a long time they were liable to fines from well-documented fraudulent activities.  If you don't like the risk put your money in FDIC bank accounts.

It is the present stockholders of JPM who get hit by the fine. Are they the ones who should be penalized? When we try to determine in detail who should be penalized, the discussion goes around and around. Should JPM pay for the sins of Bear Stearns? Should Bear Stearns employees in areas other than derivatives be penalized for the sins of other departments? (They were, by the way.)

There is certainly enough responsibility to go around. The people who deserve to be penalized are the people who made these decisions, the other people in the industry who let it happen, and the people in other industries who were too busy with their own concerns to notice or care that the mortgage area was getting increasingly lucrative and increasingly rotten and dishonest.

The people who should be penalized are those who did it, let it happen, and believed that strict regulation of markets was not necessary. The people who should be penalized are those who did well while the bubble was inflating and popping.

This would be technically very simple to do. It would be unfair in specific circumstances, but so would anything else. Just raise taxes on the very rich and the income on their investments, and many responsible people will be penalized along with a minority that does not deserve it but can afford it.

Consumers shopping for coverage off of the ACA exchanges won’t qualify for subsidies. So, if you want the subsidy, you have to go to the exchange after you've been dropped.  And, for many, the new policies are not affordable without a subsidy.

Very amusing, but in the meanwhile, what about the President's promise that if you like your policy, you can keep it.   Oh, never mind, I forgot we wouldn't know what was in the Act until it was passed, thanks Nancy Pelosi.

skeptic, New York:

After tripping all over themselves to explain why the president's claim was not a complete fabrication, democrats now find themselves with hundreds of thousands of constituents whose policies and doctors will, in fact, change.

Sen. Ron Johnson (R-Wis.) said he is going to propose a bill called something like "If You Like Your Health Plan, You Can Keep It."

That one-year delay being sought by democrats provides cover for myriad problems.

I assume the writers of this column don't understand that those who have to obtain new policies because the ones they have will not meet the minimum requirements next year have until the End of this year to select/ buy new insurance. They DONOT have to go through the exchange to get health care. They can go DIRECTLY to the insurance company to buy their policies and not be part of the exchange.

Do they also know that EVERY year millions of employees who get insurance through their employees are given a couple of weeks in November to select their insurance and other benefits for the new year.

Maybe not all, but at least some of the BC policies you refer to were probably the traditional hospitalization only policies that some blues continued to offer (and which were the original BC policy).  These were policies that covered hospitalization (&related expenses) only. No outpatient doctor services. etc. They were much much less expensive than comprehensive policies, and I find it difficult to imagine significant numbers of people didn't know what they were buying.
If the system cost 6 billion it was a bargain compared to the 24 billion the idiocy of the shutdown cost us.

Not sure where you were last year, but there were multiple lawsuits against the law which went to the Supreme Court which held the law to be CONSTITUTIONAL even though the court is conservative.
This law requires that there be a minimum set of benefits offers with a medical insurance policy - bronze policy. From there people have the choice to buy more expensive benefits.
Not sure if you are aware but thre are already certain minimum standards that every car must meet before it can be sold in the US. No one has been put in concentration camps as a result. In fact , tons of lives have been saved.

Those insurance companies can't extend their policies, because those policies are in violation of the ACA law - and the Democratic party steadfastly refuses to modify ACA in any way, shape or form. And the law can't be modified by fiat, as we are not that kind of country - yet.

@mark k--$329,000,000.00 is a lot of magnitude. The project is complicated, but if a large business were to have it done, it would work and it would likely be at least one order of magnitude cheaper. And the vendor, using open source code, would have made a decent profit.

I would disagree on the point that money was wasted, firstly think of the people who did the job? same as perhaps you who are working somewhere. Secondly there are always advancements and things we don't know about even 5 years back, if I was to say that MSFT wasted monies on win95, 98 ... upto windows 8 that would be wrong you know what I mean.

Now comming back to topic, think about the people who would improve the system and take it to next level? I would say that it doesnot require someone to be extraordinary to fix it to a level that even the PHD's from MIT can't. However I sure hope General Contractor means anyone can opt in and contribute towards it even from outside US.

"Once the computer system is up and running, what other problems will there be."

***
Sticker shock.

Andrea's pithy comment understates the case.

Perhaps we need another high official to hold a press conference to follow-up on "We have to pass the bill (ACA) so that you can find out what's in it," with

"We have to turn on the machine" (website) "to find out what it does."

In many ways a black box with a singe, red Push Here button. If that button ends up destroying insurance and physician coverage -- for millions of people, then I suppose this would merely be the simple cost of an experiment.

I am all for making the health care system better and getting coverage for preexisting conditions but am really concerned about what comes next. Once the computer system is up and running, what other problems will there be. HAs anyone really thought this out. I also would like to know how much money was wasted on this inferior system. The President assures us by saying he now has the best and the brightest working on the fixes...where were they when this thing was being designed and implemented. Classic government wasting our money.

It sounds like the NY website has problems of its own and I hope they will be resolved for you soon.  You should be able to pick from SILVER, GOLD, and PLATINUM plans that have lower deductibles and wider coverage networks if you prefer.  They will probably carry higher premiums - indeed quite a bit higher than most cell phone plans.  But please note that the bronze plan you have quoted is pretty inexpensive by health insurance standards.  Prior to the passage of the ACA, unless your health insurance company deemed you to be young and in perfect health, you would almost certainly be looking at costs above $637 a month.  I agree that the identity questions asked are kind of creepy, but believe me they are much less intrusive than 10-page questionnaires about your health history.
Vaughn, we could (in theory) make healthcare available to all simply and cheaply -- see my reply (above) to JT.
Actually, no more diesels or V-8's is not a bad idea.  Once you go electric, you never go back.

Thus Gene Amparo: "The media should avoid giving the problems with the health care website too much importance. Whatever the website problems are, they do not justify the stance of tea party Republicans who seek any excuse to delay, defund or repeal Obamacare."

I disagree, because the mandate is an imposition by the government on what we must do. We _must_ have insurance, and by a certain date, but the government's own action has deprived many of us of our plans, and government's incompetence has deprived us of the ability to get them in times to satisfy the government's demand.

This is not only unjust, but it's a little absurdist.

Our relationship to our government is of enormous interest to me in any matter where I can be penalized for not doing the impossible.

In almost all industrial countries, the healthcare system is only about 7-8% of the economy, not one-sixth. In Germany, this is accomplished through private insurance companies, even though it is mandated and subsidized by the government. They just don't let greed rule everything.

Jan - I agree.  Alaska is a US state.  Alaska has over 100,000 'subsistence' residents who primarily live off the land.  Many of these residents live in very isolated villages or live by themselves in areas only accessed by snowmobile or dog sled - there are NO roads and no internet access.  The ridiculous ACA law says all these people must buy health insurance soon or face severe IRS penalties.  It should be hilarious to see IRS agents trying to drive dog sleds into the Alaskan wilderness to kick in the doors of these people and seize their assets because they REFUSE to sign up for useless 'Bronze' insurance polices !

How many people know no one with a mobile device and have no access to a library, though? Some people don't have phones at all--but unless they're living in a rural area far from any internet hotspot and any neighbors, the scenario you're describing seems extremely rare.

Less than third world? Are you kidding?

Please tell me the last third-world country you visited and when you went.

This country is incredibly advanced--like no other country on the planet. Ever been to rural Mexico? How about rural India? But we're the stupid ones? Wow.

Many people that need this service do not have computers.  Not everyone can just go on line and sign up.  Not everyone has a smart phone or even service to provide connection to anything. Even in this day and age, some don't have phones. This country is not advanced.  This country leaves too many behind.  Our infrastructure is less than third world.  We pay for wars and give tax cuts. We are exceptional in our stupidity.

Perhaps but I don't see this limited to the government vs. private companies, you just don't hear about it. Private company Microsoft just released Windows 8.1 and had to pull it from the market because it was bricking many computers. Same thing. And if they have to put off the roll-out with delays in deadlines so what? Big deal, we created the deadlines we can change them. State exchanges are working well, healthcare.gov already works to a great extent, thousands are being signed up every day, and you must admit that it will likely be better or much better in six weeks.
One does not plan to get cancer either.
